NewWords.WordPhrase: ad.，prep.  on or into (a ship, train, aircraft, bus, etc.) 在（船、车、飞机等）上  come aboard (fig) become a new member of an organization 入伙，加盟
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. New employees who came aboard in the last six weeks have not been tested.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  理发师
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I'm going to the barber's (shop) to get my hair cut.

NewWords.WordPhrase: num. （美、法）十亿；（英、德）万亿
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This country is more than two billion US dollars in debt.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 亿万富翁；大富翁
v. mix together thoroughly（将…）混合   blend in mix harmoniously 融洽，十分协调
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. As a newlly-appointed manager, he was not sure whether he could blend in.

NewWords.WordPhrase: according to what everyone says 人人都说
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Chinese football team will play the Koreans tonight. It should be a match worth watching, by all accounts.

NewWords.WordPhrase: behave in a wild or improper way；conduct；continue 举止随便；进行；继续做
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There's nothing unusual about them. They carry on just like everybody else.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. famous person 名人
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. celebrities of stage and screen 演艺界名人

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  (of a person) happy in a lively way; (of sth.) making one feel happy 愉快的；令人愉快的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They are both very cheerful in spite of their colds.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 公司的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Corporate executives usually have high salaries.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  球场
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Are the players on court yet.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. improve by care, training or study; develop 培养，陶冶
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They encourage students to cultivate special interests in theoretical physics.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 民主党人；民主主义者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This is the time for democrats and not dictators（独裁者）.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  be worthy of 应受，值得
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I am only partly responsible for the success of this book. My collaborator（合作者）deserves more credit.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （美国、加拿大的）10分硬币
n.  amount of money, which may be taken off the full price 折扣
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Traditional retailers who've opened cyberstores （网上商店）may offer special discounts to online shoppers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 雇员，受雇者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The manager sacked 3 employees.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 雇佣者，雇主
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We need a reference from your former employer before we can give you a definite job offer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n., a. 经营管理方面的（人员）；行政方面的（人员）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She's an executive in a computer company.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  attracting attention by being too smart and decorated 浮华的, 华而不实的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. a flashy sports car

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (usu. pl) people in general 人们；人民
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They got married and had kids and lived like other folks.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. simple and friendly 友好的，坦率的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Steven comes from a folksy town in South California.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the quality of being willing to give money, help, etc. 慷慨，大方
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There are stories about his generosity, the massive amounts of money he gave to charities.

NewWords.WordPhrase: do (sth.) without being caught or punished 做(某事)而未被发觉或未受惩罚
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They claimed that they knew how to play the system and get away with it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. information given out in the form of a printed sheet, leaflet 印刷品, 宣传品
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Official handouts describe the president as "particularly noted as a scholar".

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （报纸上的）标题
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The headlines in the newspapers were to please millions of people in China: Beijing to host the 2008 Olympic Games.

NewWords.WordPhrase: keep to 遵守, 不改变
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. John holds to his belief that you can be successful as long as you work hard.

NewWords.WordPhrase: establish 制定；设立
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Conditions for membership are laid down in the soccer club rules.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. likely (to do sth.) 有可能做…的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The sports meeting is liable to be postponed until next week because of the bad weather.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of a particular place 地方的，当地的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Three-quarters of the investment needed to host the Olympics would be borne by central and local government.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. being true and faithful (to) 忠诚
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My father is a soccer fan. His loyalty to the local team has taken him all over the country to see them play.

NewWords.WordPhrase: form; constitute 构成，组成
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Women make up nearly 50% of university entrants.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a large house, usu. belonging to a rich person (豪华的)宅邸，大厦
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His mansion is located up a small hill.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 市长
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The mayor cut the ribbon（彩带）for the opening ceremony.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a note of sth. to be remembered 备忘录
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. an inter-office memo 内部备忘录

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. covered in mud 沾满泥的；泥泞的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When it rains the ground becomes very muddy.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in flight; continuously active 奔逃，逃避；忙个不停
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I have been on the run all day and I am exhausted.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) 开门；打开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Open up, or I break in.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the act of becoming or making open, esp. officially （正式的）开张，开幕
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The minister made a speech at the opening of the bridge.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 期权，购买（或出售）权；选择自由   stock option  优先认股权
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We have an option on the piece of land.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 牧师
n. (infml) keen activity and energy 劲头，活力
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The young man is full of pep.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a light van having an open body with low sides 小卡车，轻型货车
v. （使）具有资格
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Highly trained staff are well qualified to give practical advice to students when they select courses.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n., v. 集会
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They held an antiwar rally.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (将…)列为（某等级）   ranking n. 地位; 等级
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is currently ranked second in the world as a tennis player.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. far away in space or time 遥远的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The supply of electricity to remote mountainous villages is one of the local development projects in Yunnan province.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 记者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The reporter finished the news article just before the deadline.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. keep for a special use; book (a seat, room, table, etc.) 将…留作专用；预定
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some seats on the buses are reserved for the old.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (使)退休  retired a. (of a person) having stopped working, usu. because of age 退休了的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Although their careers are important they plan to retire at 50.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. give (sth.) to sb. in return for work or services 奖赏
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The officer is to be rewarded for his efforts with promotion to the rank of inspector.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 阴谋；计划  schemer n. 阴谋家
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. All the schemes and intrigues（阴谋诡计）are doomed to failure.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 奖学金
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some companies have set up scholarships for both students and teachers at our university.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (AmE) 猎枪弹；炮弹；壳
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Shells burst over the city.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. 叹气，叹息
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He sighed for the days of his youth.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. 驾驶  steer clear of keep away from 避开，避免
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Children are told to steer clear of troublemakers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. unwilling to spend money 吝啬的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He tried to save money without being stingy.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 资本；股票，证券
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You'd better get professional advice before buying stocks or bonds.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sb.) very surprised 使惊吓
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We were completely stunned by her hostile reaction.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 系统
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. the nervous system 神经系统

NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) 盛气凌人
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Mr. Smith is not much of a manager. He always throws his weight around.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 龙卷风
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The town was hit by a tornado.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 对待；待遇
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Like everyone else, I resent his cruel treatment of his old father.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 皮夹子
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I keep my driver's license in my wallet.
